thread.title: Second bid for 1,300-job manufacturing complex in Sunderland to be made

author: Graeme Whitfield
title: Second bid for 1,300-job manufacturing complex in Sunderland to be made
text:
A CGI of how Wear Point 55 could look (Image: Anna Rainbow PR) Share Get business updates directly to your inbox + Subscribe Thank you for subscribing! Could not subscribe, try again later Invalid Email 
Developers are preparing a second bid for a £70m development in the North East that could create 1,300 jobs - but clashes with one of the North East’s main jobs sites. 
The Town End Farm Partnership wants to build a massive manufacturing complex on land it owns next to the Nissan site at Sunderland, saying that a major supplier in the automotive sector is interested in setting up there. 
But its plans were last year knocked back by Sunderland City Council over concerns that it would put at risk the larger International Advanced Manufacturing Park (IAMP) scheme, which itself is aiming to create 5,000 jobs in the region’s automotive industry. 
Now the company has announced new plans for the site and say that its proposals can be delivered more quickly than the IAMP being planned by Sunderland and South Tyneside councils. 
The company, which is also appealing against Sunderland Council’s decision to refuse planning permission, says getting its development approved is crucial to meet Nissan’s new car production timescales and expansion plans. 
Town End, which is run by the people behind wholesalers Kans and Kandy in Seaham, has owned the 55-acre site for a decade. 
Director Peter Razaq said: “Our development will secure investment to support the future growth of arguably the region’s most important employer in Nissan . 
“This comes at a time when businesses across the country are looking for reassurances that trade and manufacturing with the UK can continue post Brexit. Our plans put the North East at the very heart of the resurgence of the country’s manufacturing sector.” 
The land around the Nissan plant is one of the most important develoment sites in the North East, with political and business leaders hoping the massive success of the Nissan plant can create thousands more jobs by encouraging supply firms to set up in the region. 
The importance of the site was reflected in the fact that it last year received £42m of the £49.7m allocated to the whole of the North East as part of a Government funding package to create jobs in the region. 
At the end of 2017, the two councils said that work could start on the site this year and that as many as 10 firms could be up and running there by autumn 2019. 
But the rival Town End plans - and the fact that it owns a substantial part of the site - suggest that developing the land could be more complicated. 
Sunderland City Council has been contacted for comment. Like us on Facebook
